clean_story:
Belief in reliability. The glue of relationships.


The word trust comes from the Old Norse traust, meaning "confidence" or "help"—like handing someone your favorite toy and knowing they’ll return it.


Trust isn’t blind faith. It’s built in small steps, like a brick wall.
Each kept promise is a brick.
A lie? A crack.
Too many cracks, and the wall collapses.


Science measures trust with the "trust game. "
Player A sends money to Player B.
Player B can keep it or send back more.
Most people return some—proving trust isn’t naive, but calculated.


Animals trust too.
Vampire bats share blood with starving roost-mates.
If one fails to reciprocate, others remember—and stop sharing.
Even bats keep score.


Broken trust isn’t always the end.
Japan’s "kintsugi" art repairs cracked pottery with gold—making it stronger because it was broken.
Some bonds work the same way.


Betrayal’s cost.
The brain on trust.
How cultures rebuild it.
